quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 10: Unit 11 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 11.9: Review: Acids, Bases, and Salts
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Comprehensive review of pH, neutralization, and salt formation

questions.question: According to the Arrhenius definition, what ion is produced by an acid when it is dissolved in water?
questions.explanation: Arrhenius acids increase the concentration of hydrogen ions (protons) when placed in an aqueous solution.

questions.question: What are the two primary products of a standard neutralization reaction between an acid and a base?
questions.explanation: In neutralization, the $\text{H}^+$ from the acid and $\text{OH}^-$ from the base form water, while the remaining ions form an ionic salt.

questions.question: Which of the following pH values indicates a solution that is considered strongly basic?
questions.explanation: The pH scale ranges from $0$ to $14$; values above $7$ are basic, with $14$ being the most strongly basic.

questions.question: What color does blue litmus paper turn when it is dipped into an acidic solution?
questions.explanation: Litmus is an indicator that turns red in the presence of an acid and stays blue in the presence of a base.

questions.question: Which mathematical relationship is used to calculate the pH of a solution from its hydrogen ion concentration?
questions.explanation: The pH is defined as the negative logarithm (base $10$) of the molar concentration of dissolved hydrogen ions.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between a strong acid and a weak acid in aqueous solution?
options: Strong acids ionize completely while weak acids only ionize partially
Strong acids are much more concentrated than any known weak acids
Strong acids always contain more hydrogen atoms in their molecules
Strong acids cannot be neutralized by the addition of a weak base
questions.explanation: Strength refers to the degree of ionization; strong acids dissociate $100\%$ into ions, whereas weak acids exist in equilibrium.

questions.question: Which of these substances is a common example of a Brønsted-Lowry base because it can accept a proton?
questions.explanation: Ammonia can accept a proton to form the ammonium ion ($\text{NH}_4^+$), fitting the Brønsted-Lowry definition of a base.

questions.question: What is formed when the hydrogen of an acid is replaced by a metal ion or another positive ion?
questions.explanation: Salts are ionic compounds produced by the reaction of an acid with a base, or by the reaction of a metal with an acid.

questions.question: Which indicator is colorless in an acidic solution but turns bright pink in a basic solution?
questions.explanation: Phenolphthalein is a popular titration indicator because of its sharp and distinct color change at a slightly basic pH.

questions.question: If a solution has a hydroxide ion concentration $[\text{OH}^-]$ of $1 \times 10^{-4}$ M, what is its pOH value?
questions.explanation: Similar to pH, pOH is the negative log of the hydroxide concentration: $\text{pOH} = -\log[\text{OH}^-]$. The negative log of $10^{-4}$ is $4$.
